data.title: A HIDDEN TREASURE TO BE EXPERIENCED!
data.text: My hubby and I went to see this Maine Jewish Museum and lo and behold we were changed by the visit.   "Kinda" hidden back off the road, in a Neighborhood once nicknamed the Jerusalem of the North, stands the Maine Jewish Museum (and the Etz Chaim Synagogue).  In the heart of downtown Portland, with other significant historical churches for neighbors of Italian, Irish, African, and Episcopalian origins, you get a fascinating chance to feel the past in the present.  There are permanent storyboards depicting Jewish Lives of Maine for more than a century, rotating art exhibitions, a plethora of cultural programs scheduled throughout the year, docent led tours as well as self guided tour handouts.  When we entered the building, there were all sorts of people working and volunteering and everyone of those people was smiling.  We hit the jackpot as we actually met and talked to the Rabbi and the Art Curator there, as well as a library archivist and the office manager.   They could not have been more friendly, more enthusiastic or more knowledgeable....and we left the building smiling too. It is handicap accessible with an elevator, and showcases how important it is to visit museums that make sure no one forgets.....

data.title: Art and Religion
data.text: Came for the multi media exhibit by a Maine Jewish artist. Museum is in synagogue. Would not have known about it but saw article in the Boston Globe.

data.title: Well Worth a Stop
data.text: If you have extra time and are interested in history, stop in this museum.  It is free and there is a very knowledgeable guide.  There are some very poignant stories from survivors of the Holocaust on the second floor.

data.title: Beautiful park, quiet, peaceful, with lovely art
data.text: A lovely synagogue is in.   the midst of beautiful gardens with enough benches throughout you can spend time to sit and enjoy. Peaceful, spititual, calm, and quiet.  The museum has lovely artwork and interesting exhibits as well as a memorial to the Holocaust victims and survivors.  Read the stories of survivors who later settled in the Portland area.  This is a good stop for the whole family and is easily located right on Congress Street.

data.title: Art, History, and Faith in a quiet and beautiful setting
data.text: From the beautiful landscape and local artwork to the inspirational stories of Holocaust survivors, the Maine Jewish Museum took us a little over an hour to visit.  It is a wonderfully restored synagogue and the story of its renovation is truly inspiring.   Visitors can sit in the peaceful synagogue, read about the history of Maine's Jewish community, and enjoy works of art by local artists.  In the upstairs gallery are photographs and poignant stories of Holocaust survivors who eventually settled in Portland and the surrounding area.

data.title: Interesting museum
data.text: The Maine Jewish Museum has some interesting art work and exhibits that detail the history of Jewish life in Maine, including remembrances from Holocaust survivors, but also from kids who went to Jewish summer camps in the state (including several famous names). If you're Jewish, you should definitely stop by. The building also houses an active congregation.

data.title: Interesting addition to the trip.
data.text: Located in an old Portland Synagogue, it was interesting to read about the the history of Maine's Jewish community, and see photos. There was also a small gallery with artwork. A bit off the beaten track, but a good stop.

data.title: A fascinating place to visit
data.text: My wife and I learned of it when we got to Portland and looked at a website with local attractions.  We spent about 75 minutes there, and would have stayed longer but it was closing time.  The woman in charge was wonderfully welcoming and gave us a nice concise history of the synagogue and museum. The small sanctuary on the ground floor and the substantially larger one on the second and third floors are historical treasures, and there are very informative and interesting postings throughout the building telling about the history of Jews in Maine.

data.title: Hidden gem
data.text: With a recently renovated building, impressive collection of Holocaust survivor stories, and the history of Jewish summer camps, the Main Jewish Museum was surprisingly well put together and informative.  Highly recommend it as part of your tour of Portland.

data.title: Beautiful Museum
data.text: I practically ran to the Maine Jewish Museum so I could get there before it closed and I am glad I did. The restored synagogue is beautiful and the exhibits are very informative and well organized. I loved the information on Jewish summer camps. There was a wonderful art exhibit and several of the works are for sale - the proceeds are donated back to the museum. There is no admission fee but I was happy to make a donation before I left.

data.title: Drenched in Color
data.text: Portland's First Friday Art Walk every month is always wonderful to attend. This month, my first visit to the Maine Jewish Museum was outstanding. Henry Isaacs  work was featured. I loved the space and the arrangement of the simply inspired and colorful work. Thank you for your hospitality.

data.title: NOT to be Missed.  A gorgeous building with many layers of history. It's not all about religion !i
data.text: Just a bit off the tourist track, but only steps from the crowds of Commercial St,  The Maine Jewish Museum, in a renovated 19th century Synagogue, has so many facets.  Go there to understand Portland's immigration history, and how Portland has come to be the most ethnically diverse city in Northern New England.  Also !  Go to see the contemporary art.  Curator  Nancy Davidson continues to put up some of Maine's most innovative exhibitions- again- not religious

data.title: an unusual location for this museum
data.text: The caretaker is exceptionally friendly and informative. There is a very moving exhibit related to Portland's Holocaust survivors.

data.title: Wonderful to see
data.text: I love visiting Jewish museums and temples. This one was  built in 1920. There was no that much to see but seeing the Bima and the old construction was interesting. There is a rabbi there to answer any questions. I looked around and made a small donation and was happy that I went to see such a antique.

data.title: Classic Synagogue Design
data.text: A wonderful preservation of an old beuatiful synagogue and of a history of the Jewish community throught Maine.  You need no more than an hour, if that.

data.title: A true hidden gem!
data.text: Located on Congress Street, the Etz Chaim Synangogue,  which is nearly 100 years old, is the home of the Maine Jewish Museum. This site is another historical entity you must see during your stay in Portland.  People of all denominations will enjoy the rich history of this museum. What is more, curator-in-residence Nancy Davidson, makes you feel a though you are part of the synagogue's community. Her vast knowledge of this synagogue makes the visit stand out. There are some excellent primary source documents from the Holocaust on the second floor. Also noteworthy, are the well-maintained front grounds. The grass is like a lush green carpet and the flowers are exquisite. A truly memorable visit awaits those who choose to see this historic property.

data.title: Get a sense of the Jewish community of Portland, past and present.
data.text: The museum as such is small and not particularly significant, although it does have several interesting photos. A walk-through will take only a short time, perhaps half an hour at most. But perhaps of greater interest is the building that houses the museum, which is one of the few remaining Jewish synagogues in Portland. It's interesting to view the synagogue itself which houses the museum and to learn a bit about the history and present situation of this very old Jewish community of Portland.

data.title: Worth a visit
data.text: We stumbled upon this historic building that used to be a home for Irish immigrants but was converted to a synagogue in the 1920's. It's recent renovation highlights the beauty of the building and is testimony to the resurgence of Portland's Jewish community. The Rabbi welcomes visitors and is happy to answer questions and provide a tour. This is a museum as well as an active temple. Maine residents who survived the Holocaust are honored in a moving exhibit of portraits and personal narratives. A new art exhibit was being installed during our visit.

user_location.name: New York, New York, United States

data.title: A Must Visit When in Portland
data.text: Very interesting experience and especially learning the history of this museum and synagogue.  Recently renovated..beautifully done and worth seeing when in Portland.  We spent 45 minutes there and met the Rabbi who was extremely nice in showing us around and explaining the history.

data.title: Very friendly rabbi
data.text: I'm not Jewish but wanted to just take a look. The rabbi was very welcoming, told us the history and current update of the community in Portland and at this particular synagogue. The artwork is routinely changed as well. It's worth a stop if you enjoy getting to know something about the local area rather than just touristy stuff.
